reviews.review_msg: Great material, but subjective marking. Two-part exams: first part - two terms you have to define. No rubric; you just have to pray that you guess what the professor wanted. Second part - essay. No feedback after grading, just an arbitrary rubric that, AGAIN, is released after the exam. If you're consodering to take it as an elective, please don't

As others have mentioned, her TAs are quite difficult graders for a first year course. I was taking third year sociology courses at the same time and receiving much better marks. It was a bit of a deterrent for me for engaging with more GSWS courses, as what is expected overall is just a bit unclear.

Carmen is a great prof. However, the issues lay within the TA's. My TA marked very subjectively, and would deduct marks for things not asked for in the questions. If your work didn't align with their opinions, marks were deducted as well it seems. Rubric was released after assignments were handed back, which made it hard to know what was wanted.

I did 100 with them, criteria was clear, assignments were fair, exams were fair. Now in 101, rubric is incredibly subjective, only revealed rubric after the exam had been graded. Exam material focuses on one specific module. Strict criteria for one 100 word question, yet only revealed this after the fact. Prof is passionate, do 100 as a gpa booster

Very passionate and knowledgeable about the topic and engages in amazing discussions.I respect her a lot. Got a better mark on the final written assignment as I tried to use some of her optional readings in my writing fyi. Attendance and participation matters but she will never make you speak if you don't want to. Understanding and deeply caring.

Dr. Fung is amazing! Also had a first year course with her, mainly marked hard by TAs and why she has lower ratings. Extremely knowledgable on the topic and her lectures are engaging. She does not believe in exams and has lots of readings, essays and attendance marks, does not make you talk if you don't want to. Very approachable and understanding.

Carman is a great prof! She puts a lot of thought and effort into making the content approachable and interesting for both beginners and veterans to gender studies. Very helpful in discussing ideas outside of class time. Relaxed class vibe, encourages participation but doesn't force individual people to talk.
They're nice and passionate about gender studies. Also makes cool assignments.

The prof is kind, approachable, and responsive to all emails in a timely manner. Only major suggestion is to implement a clear grading rubric for essays. Also, her and the TAs deduct marks for not including a minor point from readings in essays, even if that point was stated in one sentence and was not the main thesis. Very very subjective grading

Carman said she would regrade my exam essay and ended up completely ignoring my email afterwards. Now I have to do a whole grade appeal, when she could have easily sticked to her words. She wouldn't even round me up even tho I was 0.4 away so don't expect to get rounded up bc she has "no criteria on rounding".

Never taking her class again.

I have no idea how a 100 level course was graded as hard as it was ... I was genuinely confused. Of course I still got an A, but I had to work disproportionately hard for it in comparison to other 100/beginner level courses. 

Content was easy, but there was so much of it. Papers were marked disproportionately hard. Hm.

Course has multiple T.A.s. My T.A. nitpicked and took off marks despite my answer being the same as her feedback. Course was interesting at first, but got boring as it went on. Most, if not the entire course, was taken from a predecessor and was slightly messy. Only 6 assignments in total. Essays were difficult and instructions were vague.

Lots of reading to do and the first assignment was pretty difficult as the questions were pulled from different readings and it was not very specified. Good class overall I guess not the best but the prof was good.
Is like an english teacher in highschool, if it is not the one answer that they expect then good luck at getting a good grade. No wiggle room for understanding concepts or even your own thoughts.
